ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Prey capture revisited
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, I also am a little confused about how you are using the kept tests, and also what constitutes a failed test in this case.  But I get the general idea.

Hi,
	I also am a little confused about how you are using the kept tests, and 
also what constitutes a "failed test" in this case.  But I get the general 
idea.

	Over on the GP mail list we had a discussion of co-evolution and one of 
the examples that was brought up was a case where the guy had far too many 
test cases to evaluate them all against each individual, so he set up the 
set of test cases to evolve for their ability to distinguish solutions, 
whilst the solutions were evolving to solve them.  Obviously there's a rick 
there of the test-cases focusing in on a limited domain (which happens to 
work well at one point in history) and the solutions losing the ability to 
operate outside that domain.  ISRT this was avoided by (i) always including 
a set of randomly chosen test-cases, (ii) scoring the test-cases in a way 
that favours those who test different aspects from the bulk of the test-cases.

	That last point might be achieved by particularly rewarding a test-case 
for any solutions it could separate but other test-cases not?

	Ian
